questions.question: 1. In the poem’s five stanzas, the poet uses the extended metaphor of his love being near the ocean to emphasize his--

choices.answer: A. Doubt she really loves him
B. Belief she likes to be near the sea
C. Concern that she will not be comfortable in her new home
D. Hope that he will one day be reunited with her

questions.question: 2. The poet’s use of figurative language in lines 19 and 20 supports the idea that he--

choices.answer: A. spent too much time worrying about an ex-lover
B. worked hard to build trust in his relationship
C. tried to cure his partner of her illness
D. mourns the death of his partner

questions.question: 3. The poet’s use of rhyme between the endings of lines 31 and 33 emphasizes his--

choices.answer: A. strong attachment to Annabel even in death
B. belief that he will never fall in love again
C. disappointment with his new relationship
D. hope that she will move back home to be with him

questions.question: 4. In the poem the author uses a metaphor of blowing winds in order to emphasize the speaker is—

choices.answer: A. determined to change his life
B. fearful of dying like Annabel
C. troubled by Annabel’s sudden death
D. eager to find a cure for diseases

questions.question: 5. What is the main feeling expressed throughout the poem?

choices.answer: A. shock
B. unease
C. grief
D. worry

questions.question: 6. The poet chose to write lines in stanza two with different lengths and with rhymes in order to--

choices.answer: A. provide hints about the poem’s hidden meaning
B. emphasize the importance of the final stanza
C. make the speaker’s words about love stand out
D. suggest the speaker has gone insane
